Title: Beethoven - Symphony No. 3, "Eroica" | Michael Tilson Thomas | New World Symphony (2017)
Description:
Ludwig van Beethoven‚Äôs Third Symphony, a triumphant homage to heroism, has been hailed as ‚Äúthe greatest single step made in the history of music.‚Äù

What we now know as the ‚ÄúEroica‚Äù Symphony (Italian for ‚ÄúHeroic‚Äù) began under the title ‚ÄúBonaparte.‚Äù Beethoven had been contemplating a work inspired by Napoleon for several years by the time he took up the symphony, and he held the revolutionary hero in high regard as of 1803. Beethoven‚Äôs adulation turned to disgust in 1804, when he learned that Napoleon had declared himself Emperor. According to Beethoven‚Äôs student Ferdinand Ries, who delivered the disturbing news, ‚ÄúBeethoven went to the table, seized the top of the [symphony‚Äôs] title-page, tore it in half and threw it on the floor.‚Äù When Beethoven prepared the symphony for publication in 1806, he titled it ‚ÄúSinfonia eroica, composed to celebrate the memory of a great man.‚Äù The ‚Äúgreat man‚Äù may have still referenced Napoleon, but some have speculated that the title actually meant to honor Prince Louis Ferdinand of Prussia, who died in 1806 fighting against Napoleon‚Äôs army. Ferdinand was a friend of Prince Joseph Franz von Lobkowitz, Beethoven‚Äôs patron and the symphony‚Äôs dedicatee. 

The ‚ÄúEroica‚Äù Symphony did not impress the Viennese public at its debut on April 7, 1805. First the audience had to grapple with the length, an unprecedented 50 minutes. (Haydn‚Äôs ‚ÄúLondon‚Äù Symphonies, by comparison, averaged about 30 minutes each.) To further complicate matters, the marathon first movement offered no real singing melodies to latch onto, just short motives and patterns that circulated and developed in novel ways. Such concision and unity became hallmarks of Beethoven‚Äôs middle-period.

-- Copyright ¬© 2017 Aaron Grad

Originally performed May 6, 2017. 

#beethoven #orchestra #eroica #mttmusic

Title: Berlioz : Symphonie Fantastique
Description:
L'Orchestre philharmonique de Radio France dirig√© par Myung-Whun Chung interpr√®te la "Symphonie fantastique" d'Hector Berlioz. Enregistr√© le 13 septembre 2013 √† la Salle Pleyel (Paris). 

#Berlioz #SymphonieFantastique #OrchestrePhilharmoniqueDeRadioFrance

00:00 - D√©but du concert
00:35 - 1er mouvement : R√™veries ‚Äì Passions (Largo)
15:08 - 2√®me mouvement : Un bal. Valse (Allegro non troppo)
22:09 - 3√®me mouvement : Sc√®ne aux champs (Adagio)
39:53 - 4√®me mouvement : Marche au supplice (Allegretto non troppo)
44:27 - 5√®me mouvement : Songe d‚Äôune nuit de sabbat (Larghetto ‚Äì Allegro)

La Symphonie fantastique a √©t√© cr√©√©e en 1830, en plein courant du romantisme, l‚Äôann√©e de la bataille d‚ÄôHernani. Premi√®re ‚Äúmusique √† programme‚Äù, qui fait √©clater le cadre strictement classique de la symphonie, elle est un chef d‚Äô≈ìuvre en avance sur son temps, influen√ßant bien des compositeurs romantiques, Liszt, Wagner ou Mahler. Narration √† la fois autobiographique et fantasm√©e de son amour pour l‚Äôactrice Harriet Smithson, l‚Äô≈ìuvre tourne autour d‚Äôune ‚Äúid√©e fixe‚Äù qui revient de fa√ßon obsessionnelle dans les diff√©rents mouvements. 

Apr√®s une Introduction lente et incertaine, l‚Äôid√©e fixe est expos√©e puis d√©velopp√©e dans le premier mouvement Allegro. Une valse l√©g√®re et c√©l√®bre retentit dans le deuxi√®me mouvement ‚Äú Un bal‚Äù,  qui s‚Äôach√®ve dans une coda effr√©n√©e. L‚ÄôAdagio de la Sc√®ne aux champs commence avec un duo hautbois / cor anglais dressant un paysage champ√™tre, avant une s√©rie de variations rappelant Beethoven. La Marche au supplice, d‚Äôune dur√©e courte, est une vision d‚Äôhorreur o√π le h√©ros s‚Äôimagine avoir tu√© sa bien-aim√©e. Le dernier mouvement, Songe d‚Äôune Nuit de Sabbat est sans doute celui qui va le plus loin dans les innovations musicales, l‚Äôannonce du Dies Irae par deux cloches sonnant dans le vide est sans doute le passage le plus effrayant.

Title: Mendelssohn 3 Philadelphia Mehta Feb 1971 Live
Description: Zubin Mehta guest conducts the Mendelssohn Symphony No. 3. It was not until 1977 that Philadelphia made a commercial recording of this symphony (on RCA, a recording I have never been able to hear), and Ormandy did not program it until just before that recording session. (By contrast, he and guest conductors programmed the Italian and Reformation symphonies with some frequency and he commercially recorded the Italian in 1963, in a Columbia recording that sounds very different to me from the live performance I have included elsewhere on this channel). A listener rightly comments below on some ensemble issues in this performance. At high amplitude the sound suffers a bit.

Title: Prokofjew - Sinfonie Nr. 5 | Cristian MƒÉcelaru | WDR Sinfonieorchester
Description:
Sergej Prokofjews Sinfonie Nr. 5 B-Dur op. 100, gespielt vom WDR Sinfonieorchester unter der Leitung von Cristian MƒÉcelaru. Live aufgenommen am 10.02.2023 in der K√∂lner Philharmonie.

Sergej Prokofjew - Sinfonie Nr. 5 B-Dur op. 100

00:00:00 I. Andante
00:14:03 II. Allegro marcato
00:23:15 III. Adagio
00:37:36 IV. Allegro giocoso

WDR Sinfonieorchester
Cristian MƒÉcelaru, Leitung

In seiner Reihe "Kurz und Klassik" spricht Chefdirigent Cristian MƒÉcelaru √ºber Prokofjews f√ºnfte Sinfonie: https://youtu.be/iE0DO_mZePE

‚ñ∫ Mehr zum Sinfonieorchester, zu Konzerten und aktuellen Livestreams gibt es bei https://sinfonieorchester.wdr.de 
‚ñ∫ Das WDR Sinfonieorchester bei Facebook https://www.facebook.com/wdrsinfonieorchester
‚ñ∫ Weitere Konzerte und Werkeinf√ºhrungen aus der Welt der klassischen Musik, Symphonic Crossover, Chorgesang und Konzerte f√ºr Kinder finden sie auch in der ARD Mediathek: https://www.ardmediathek.de/klassik 

Werkeinf√ºhrung:
Moskau, Juni 1944. Inmitten des Zweiten Weltkrieges herrschen in der Hauptstadt der Sowjetunion Hunger und Wohnungsnot. Sergej Prokofjew bewohnt gemeinsam mit seiner Frau ein Zimmer im Hotel Moskwa, unweit des Roten Platzes. Doch die Bedingungen sind auch hier alles andere als ideal. An Komponieren ist nicht zu denken. Da erl√∂st ihn die Einladung, den Sommer im Haus des Komponistenverbandes in Iwanowo zu verbringen. Am Rande der 250 Kilometer n√∂rdlich von Moskau gelegenen Stadt finden sich weite W√§lder und viel Natur. Prokofjew macht ausgedehnte Spazierg√§nge und f√ºhlt sich an seine Kindheit erinnert, die er auf einem Landgut verbrachte. Er wei√ü, dass von ihm in jenen Kriegszeiten ein heroisches Werk erwartet wird. In Iwanowo komponiert er tats√§chlich eine repr√§sentative Sinfonie, die jedoch √ºber die Zeitumst√§nde deutlich hinausreicht. √Ñhnlich wie Bart√≥k in seinem 2. Violinkonzert vollzieht auch Prokofjew in seiner F√ºnften eine Synthese seines bisherigen Schaffens. Seine Erste und auch die Vierte schlagen neoklassizistische T√∂ne an, w√§hrend die Zweite und die Dritte eher wild, dissonant, ja teilweise roh daherkommen. Nun, in der F√ºnften, ist der Stil gem√§√üigt, und die Musik entwickelt sich mit gro√üen epischen B√∂gen.

Schon nach zwei Monaten ist die Komposition vollendet, sodass Prokofjew am 26. August die Komponistenkollegen, die ebenfalls in Iwanowo weilen, zusammenruft, darunter auch Dmitrij Schostakowitsch. Auf dem Klavier spielt Prokofjew ihnen das neue Werk vor. Dmitrij Kabalewskij erinnert sich: "Die Sinfonie hinterlie√ü bei uns allen einen starken Eindruck, und wir machten aus unserer Begeisterung keinen Hehl. Prokofjew war sehr befriedigt ‚Äì hielt er dieses Opus doch immer f√ºr eins seiner besten Werke." Anfang 1945 dirigiert der Komponist selbst die Urauff√ºhrung. Als er bereits den Taktstock gehoben hat, klingen pl√∂tzlich Kanonensalven in den Gro√üen Saal des Moskauer Konservatoriums herein und verk√ºnden den sowjetischen Sieg an der Weichsel ‚Äì eine historische Konnotation voller Ambivalenz.

Text: Otto Hagedorn

Title: Schumann: Manfred Overture | Daniel Harding & the Verbier Festival Orchestra
Description:
Robert Schumann thought of his incidental music ‚ÄúManfred: Dramatic Poem with Music in Three Parts‚Äù, Op. 115 as something completely new and unprecedented. Later musicians regarded the overture to Manfred as being especially original. To this day, it is considered one of the best orchestral works that Schumann composed. The Verbier Festival Orchestra performs under the direction of Daniel Harding. The concert took place on July 29, 2010 at the Verbier Festival.
 
Robert Schumann's (1810 - 1856) idea for ‚ÄúManfred‚Äù was to write a ‚Äúliterary opera‚Äù. He intended to bring together his two passions, music and literature. The text for the dramatic poem is based on the poem ‚ÄúManfred‚Äù by the British poet Lord Byron (1788 - 1824). Its titular hero - a typical romantic anti-hero - is deeply conflicted and fails at everything. He feels guilty about the death of his lover Astarte. With the help of dark forces, he seeks contact with Astarte. The spirits cannot help Manfred, and an abbot cannot persuade him to repent. When Manfred dies, it is unclear whether his soul will find redemption.
 
Robert Schumann read Byron's poem at a young age. In the summer of 1848, he read it again in Karl Adolf Suckow's translation and decided to create a new musical-literary genre based on the material. He shortened the text of the poem but retained its three-part form. His Dramatic Poem with Music, composed in 1848/49, has a strange form for the time: In addition to the overture, there are 15 short movements spread over three sections and of different types: vocal solos, vocal ensembles, instrumental interludes, choruses, melodramas.
 
Schumann composed the overture to ‚ÄúManfred‚Äù in the fall of 1848. It seems that the Romantic composer had planned it from the outset as a concert piece to be performed separately without the dramatic parts. Such concert overtures had become established in the 19th century. In terms of form, they only vaguely corresponded to a sonata movement and instead placed programmatic themes in the foreground. The Manfred Overture was premiered on March 14, 1852 in Leipzig - with Robert Schumann conducting. The printed edition of the overture, intended for concertante purposes, was published in October 1852, a piano reduction in January 1853.

Schumann was unable to assert himself with his new genre of ‚Äúliterary opera‚Äù, possibly because Richard Wagner (1813 - 1883) had caused a sensation everywhere with his new form of opera, the music drama. Nevertheless, Schumann's Manfred Overture, Op. 115 has become established as part of the concert repertoire. Clara Schumann considered the orchestral piece to be the most magnificent thing her husband Robert had created.

¬© ID√âALE AUDIENCE ‚Äì Museec ‚Äì ARTE France ‚Äì 2010

Title: Mendelssohn 5 Philadelphia Ormandy Apr 1974 Live
Description: Eugene Ormandy conducts Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 5 ("Reformation").  This upload begins with an interview with the recently-departed (typing this in November of 2025) Benita Valente, who in the first half of this concert sang a Mozart concert aria and Bach Cantata No. 51, separately uploaded into this channel.  (Unfortunately, there is some technical glitch that periodically affects her audibility in the interview.)  The Mendelssohn is gorgeous and exciting.  It has never been commercially recorded by Philly.  There's a Muti EMI CD with Mendelssohn and Liszt, but the Mendelssohn is all Philharmonia.  There's a YNS DG CD with all 5 Mendelssohn symphonies, but with the Chamber Orchestra of Europe.  EO programmed the Reformation symphony four times in the '50s and '60s, and took it to Carnegie Hall in 1945, receiving an Olin Downes review that, while focused on exalting the performance of Prokofiev's Alexander Nevsky, did pause to say that the Mendelssohn was "distinguished by its fine tonal values, its perception and taste."  The same can be said for this performance.  The brass acquit themselves particularly well.
